user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of ws_receive_frame:
```c
static unsigned char *
ws_receive_frame (unsigned char *frame, ssize_t *length, int *type)
{
  unsigned char masks[4];
  unsigned char mask;
  unsigned char *msg;
  unsigned char flength;
  unsigned char idx_first_mask;
  unsigned char idx_first_data;
  size_t data_length;
  int i;
  int j;

  msg = NULL;
  if (frame[0] == (WS_FIN | WS_OPCODE_TEXT_FRAME))
  {
    *type = WS_OPCODE_TEXT_FRAME;
    idx_first_mask = 2;
    mask = frame[1];
    flength = mask & 0x7F;
    if (flength == 126)
    {
      idx_first_mask = 4;
    }
    else if (flength == 127)
    {
      idx_first_mask = 10;
    }
    idx_first_data = (unsigned char) (idx_first_mask + 4);
    data_length = (size_t) *length - idx_first_data;
    masks[0] = frame[idx_first_mask + 0];
    masks[1] = frame[idx_first_mask + 1];
    masks[2] = frame[idx_first_mask + 2];
    masks[3] = frame[idx_first_mask + 3];
    msg = malloc (data_length + 1);
    if (NULL != msg)
    {
      for (i = idx_first_data, j = 0; i < *length; i++, j++)
      {
        msg[j] = frame[i] ^ masks[j % 4];
      }
      *length = (ssize_t) data_length;
      msg[j] = '\0';
    }
  }
  else if (frame[0] == (WS_FIN | WS_OPCODE_CON_CLOSE_FRAME))
  {
    *type = WS_OPCODE_CON_CLOSE_FRAME;
  }
  else
  {
    *type = frame[0] & 0x0F;
  }
  return msg;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No compiler language extensions are used in the provided function. Specifically:
- There are no compiler-specific keywords or constructs such as __attribute__, __asm__, __builtin_*, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, or other vendor-specific extensions that compilers explicitly document as extensions.
- No inline assembly or pragmas are present.
- All control-flow and type usage is standard C (standard integer and pointer types, casts, array indexing, bitwise ops, loops, function return).  
- The use of ssize_t and size_t are library/ABI types (ssize_t is a POSIX typedef provided by system headers) rather than a compiler language extension; their presence does not itself indicate a compiler language extension (if required, the project should ensure the appropriate headers are included).  
- Calls to malloc are standard C library usage, not a language extension.

Given the code shown, there are no fragments that match compiler-documented language extensions and therefore nothing to flag for MISRA C:2023 Rule 1.2.
